page.title: 03INDUSTRY USWORTH/SPRINGWELL
page.content: {Springwell quarry}is 60 years old, 120 feet deep and mines carboniferous rock which is about 250 million years old. The stone is used for{building, {grindstones and hardcore.} At the bottom of the quarry was a small hut which was hardly ever seen by anybody so it was named "Seldom Seen". From the C18th{coal mining}was the area's main industry. Today the {landscape}shows evidence of mining but there are no working pits.In 1855 two shafts were sunk at Wardley, called{Follingsby Pit.}Later in 1948, Wardley and Usworth, which was nearby, were joined, but Usworth shaft was closed in August 1974 because of exhaustion of valuable reserves. The land on which{Usworth Colliery stood has been reclaimed and part of it has been used as the site for Sulgrave Village.
